byline.contributor: Kareem Fahim and Merna Thomas contributed reporting.

abstract: Residents of Cairo report nearly constant feelings of tension, isolation and fear after escalating antigovernment violence that began with 2011 Arab Spring uprising; human rights advocates blame government crackdowns for creating continuous cycle of repression and militant reaction, even from protesters who were previously nonviolent; extremists calling themselves part of Islamic State.claim responsibility for latest in long string of bombings.
lead_paragraph: At least 29 people were wounded in an attack on a branch of the Egyptian security agency, adding to a wave of militant violence in the capital over the summer.

headline.main: Egyptians Adapt as Cairo Is Redefined by a String of Bomb Attacks
headline.print_headline: Egyptians Adapt as Cairo Is Redefined by a String of Bomb Attacks

snippet: At least 29 people were wounded in an attack on a branch of the Egyptian security agency, adding to a wave of militant violence in the capital over the summer.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
